content.text: The const keyword was introduced in ES6 (2015). Use const when the variable value should not be reassigned. It must be initialised at declaration.

content.title: Immutable Binding
code: // PI = 3;   // TypeError: Assignment to constant variable

content.title: Initialisation at Declaration
code: // const LIMIT;    // SyntaxError: Missing initializer in const declaration

content.text: const prevents reassigning the variable, but it does NOT make the object immutable. Properties can still be changed.

content.title: const Object — Properties Can Change
code: // person = {};  // TypeError — reassigning const is not allowed

content.title: const Array — Elements Can Change
code: // colors = [];  // TypeError — reassigning const is not allowed

content.text: Best practice: use const by default. Switch to let only when you know the value needs to change. Never use var in modern code.
